stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on developing a new western-themed level, provisionally named 'Grandstand Badlands'. He worked on creating and implementing cowboy-themed NPCs, including a Shy Guy and a Monty Mole, which involved modeling, texturing, and coding their behavior. The stream also featured significant discussions on level design philosophy, narrative tone, and technical collaboration with team members Biobak and Zeina.

development_findings.summary: A star mechanic from a previous hack, 'Peach's Fury', is being reused in the western level because Kaze was fond of it.
development_findings.quote: We had a star like this in Peach's Fury and I liked it so much that I decided to bring it back.

development_findings.summary: The western level will feature multiple unique boss fights, a departure from other levels. One involves a shootout with five Goombas who were previously disguised in a trench coat.
development_findings.quote: This is gonna be where you're actually gonna have a shootout with five Goombas... they go 'this town ain't big enough for the six of us'.

development_findings.summary: An old Shy Guy model had to be refactored to support the game's modern world lighting system, as it was too old to have it initially.
Kaze is second-guessing a design choice to fill an area with oversized props, feeling it doesn't fit the desired vibe and was a result of desperation.
development_findings.quote: I was just kind of desperate to fill this area with something and I thought what if I just have random oversized Western related props... I'm not a hundred percent on the idea.

development_findings.summary: The team is unable to use the F3DEX3 microcode at the moment due to a significant (20%) performance penalty compared to their current solution.
development_findings.quote: I imported f3dx3 and it decreased FPS by 20%.

development_findings.summary: The team is developing a diverse set of cowboy-themed NPCs, including Yoshis, Toads, Monty Moles, Shy Guys, Snifits, and Goombas, to make the town feel alive and cohesive.
The new western level is provisionally named 'Grandstand Badlands' after brainstorming with the stream chat.
development_findings.quote: Grandstand Badlands, it's kind of a smooth name. Yeah, let's just temporarily name it that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong aversion to digital movement controls in 3D games, citing the Spyro Reignited Trilogy emulating a D-pad on the analog stick as a major design flaw.
development_findings.quote: I remember playing Spyro on PS1 and instantly I was like dude this game is shit and I realized it was because of the d-pad.

context_findings.summary: Kaze claims he avoids burnout by being soulless and robot-like in his work ethic, valuing discipline over motivation.
context_findings.quote: I actually never suffer from burnout. And that's because I do not have a soul.

context_findings.summary: Kaze prioritizes gameplay and world-building over narrative, planning to write the plot last to fit the completed levels.
context_findings.quote: Plot in Mario games is kind of very secondary.

context_findings.summary: Kaze immerses himself in relevant media (cowboy movies) to inform and inspire his level design, a process he calls 'method acting'.
context_findings.quote: The last two weeks have actually been crazy. I've been watching so many cowboy movies. I've been basically method acting designing a video game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze feels he has recently undergone significant skill growth, and the new western level is the first to fully showcase this improvement, featuring purposeful and thematic design.
context_findings.quote: I feel like recently I have leveled up a lot of my skills and this level is like the first one that has those applied and I'm pretty happy with it. It's very thematic, everything is purposeful and I like that a lot.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is reconsidering the game's core plot, feeling that a 'Yoshi slave labor' storyline might be too dark and may be simplified to a standard kidnapping plot.
context_findings.quote: I might have to slightly reshape the story, the whole Yoshi slave labor plot is maybe a bit too dark.

context_findings.summary: Kaze jokes about his future child with Zeina, indicating that game development and his personal life are closely intertwined.
context_findings.quote: If my child grows up to call my UVs terrible, they're getting put up for adoption.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's philosophy on optimization has evolved; he now believes focusing on triangle count is misguided for N64 development and is willing to use more polygons than he previously would have.
context_findings.quote: Triangle count is completely overrated. In fact, it's so overrated I have a whole video about how overrated it is... I didn't know how useless triangle count optimizations were until just recently. That's why he was so low poly at the beginning. But now that I know, we can just add more.

biobak.summary: Provided feedback on Kaze's new pipe models, suggesting they shouldn't be smooth-shaded.
Submitted his own version of the pipe model, which Kaze analyzed and found technically flawed because it disabled lighting, which would break environment mapping.
Created and sent a new hat model for the Yoshi NPCs.

zeina.summary: Created the dragon model for the treasure hunt star.
Modeled the dead trees and rock assets for the western level by hand.
Engaged with Kaze in the stream chat, asking technical questions about the assets she created and offering feedback.
zeina.quote: Are these mirrored or are these different ribs?

zeina.summary: Is also creating cowboy-themed NPC models, including a Goomba and a Koopa Troopa ('Senor Koopa').

key_stories.title: Crafting the Cowboy Shy Guy
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to create a convincing cowboy vest for a Shy Guy NPC. After trying and failing with painted textures and alpha channels, he successfully created the look by modeling the vest and holster as new geometry, demonstrating a trial-and-error approach to character design.
key_stories.challenge: A Shy Guy NPC needed to be redesigned into a convincing cowboy, requiring a hat, vest, and holster, without looking awkward on the simple base model.
key_stories.process: Kaze first tried painting a vest texture, which looked flat and 'jaggedy'. He then attempted to use an alpha channel texture, but it looked like a 'sick flap'. Finally, he decided to model the vest and holster as separate geometric pieces, adjusting their shape and connection to the body until it looked acceptable.
key_stories.outcome: After multiple failed attempts, Kaze successfully created a cowboy Shy Guy by modeling a polygonal vest and holster, rounding out the arms, and adjusting the animations. He deemed the final result a 'bad boy' that fit the level's vibe.
key_stories.key_quote: It still just looks like he's wearing a vest that is way too small for him. Not like he's a dangerous cowboy criminal.

key_stories.title: Rethinking the Wilderness
key_stories.summary: Kaze created a 'wilderness' area for the western world filled with oversized props but grew dissatisfied with the concept. He debated the design live on stream, acknowledging it felt 'desperate,' and began brainstorming new, more purposeful ideas like a rising temple, showcasing his iterative and self-critical design process.
key_stories.challenge: The second area of the new western level felt empty and needed to be filled with content that was both thematically appropriate and interesting.
key_stories.process: Kaze implemented an area with large, surreal props like a giant horseshoe and gun. Upon review during the stream, he expressed his own dissatisfaction. He then openly discussed the problem with his audience, soliciting and reacting to ideas for a more engaging and cohesive area concept.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze decided his initial idea of random oversized props was not working. He brainstormed alternatives with chat, including a lost temple that rises from the ground or a giant hawk's nest, though no final decision was made. The area remains a work in progress.
key_stories.key_quote: I was just kind of desperate to fill this area with something and I thought what if I just have random oversized Western related props... I agree... that's why I'm not a hundred percent on this area either really.

key_stories.title: The Plot is Too Dark
key_stories.summary: Kaze realized the game's 'Yoshi slave labor' plot was likely too dark. He decided to postpone a final narrative decision, planning to adjust the story to fit the feel of the completed game, illustrating his 'gameplay-first' design philosophy.
key_stories.challenge: The game's main plot, described as 'Yoshi slave labor,' felt tonally inconsistent and 'a bit too dark' for a Mario-style game.
key_stories.process: Kaze raised the issue himself, noting the tonal dissonance. He reasoned that since plot is secondary in Mario games, it's better to finalize the levels first and then write a story that fits the gameplay, rather than being constrained by a problematic early concept.
key_stories.outcome: The plot is being reconsidered and will likely be changed to a more traditional story of Bowser kidnapping the Yoshis. The final decision is deferred until after the levels are complete.
key_stories.key_quote: I'll be honest we might have to slightly reshape the story, the whole Yoshi slave labor plot is maybe a bit too dark maybe it's more like just Bowser kidnaps the Yoshi.

open_questions.topic: Silas and the Yoshi Squishiness Rework
open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that a contributor named Silas had a 'cool idea' to rework the 'squishiness function' for Yoshi.
questions: Who is Silas and what is his role on the team?
What was the 'cool idea' for the squishiness function?
How does this new function change how Yoshi feels to play?
What was the process for collaborating with Silas on this feature?

open_questions.context: Kaze stated the main plot about 'Yoshi slave labor' might be 'too dark' and is considering changing it to a simpler kidnapping story. He said the plot will be decided after the levels are done.
questions: What was the original vision for the 'Yoshi slave labor' story?
What specific moments or ideas made you feel it was too dark for the game?
How does the team, especially Zeina, feel about this potential narrative shift?
How do you balance telling a more mature story with the classic Mario tone?

open_questions.context: Kaze and Biobak had a detailed discussion about new pipe models. Biobak sent a version that Kaze critiqued for having lighting disabled, which broke other effects.
questions: Can you walk me through the collaborative process with Biobak on asset creation?
How do you typically resolve technical disagreements like the one with the pipe model?
How often does the team provide feedback that leads to significant changes?
Biobak, what was your intention with the pipe redesign you submitted?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentioned that he brought back a star design from a previous project, 'Peach's Fury,' and fantasized about making a whole game with stars like that.
questions: What was 'Peach's Fury' and what was its core concept?
What is the specific star mechanic from that game that you admire so much?
How do you decide which ideas from past projects are worth bringing into a new one?
Why do you think a hack with 200 of those stars would be 'the most popular hack of all time'?

open_questions.context: Zeina is Kaze's wife and a key contributor, providing models for dragons, trees, and NPCs. She was active in the stream chat.
questions: Kaze, Zeina, how would you describe your collaborative dynamic working on the game as a married couple?
How do you separate your personal relationship from your professional one when making creative decisions?
Can you give an example of a time you had a creative disagreement and how you resolved it?
Zeina, what's your perspective on the project's direction and your role within it?
